results.title: Broken blossoms [DVD]
results.creator_credit: D.W. Griffith and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: A young Chinese man, disillusioned by life in London, shelters the daughter of a brutish prize fighter, whom he has adored at a distance. Her father, alerted by an informer, comes after them. This is a deceptively simple chamber piece (most of it takes place in two interior sets) in contrast to the epic scale of Intolerance and Birth of a Nation. Griffith’s ties with Victorian theatre and literature were blended with the visual resources of the cinema in a new lyrically intense romanticism, the perfect context for Gish’s unforgettable portrayal of quiet vulnerability complemented by Barthelmess’s gentle emotionalism. Tinted version with musical soundtrack. Cast: Lillian Gish, Richard Barthelmess, Donald Crisp.

results.title: Storm over Asia = Potomok Chingis-Khana
results.brief_description: Set during the British occupation of Mongolia in 1920, this is the half heroic, half ironic story of Bair, a young Mongolian hunter-turned-partisan who is captured. A document in his possession identifies him as a descendent of Genghis Khan. The interventionists decide to ‘resurrect’ him as a puppet king. However Bair escapes and leads the Mongolian army against the interventionists. The intensity of the drama, strong feeling for landscape and dramatic use of montage (four or five times the usual number of shots for a feature of this length) have been compared with the work of D.W. Griffith. In effect, the film is one long chase which takes on mythic proportions while the plot takes on metaphoric and lyrical dimensions (the British army is literally ‘blown away’). The emotional impact disguises the methodological rigour of Pudovkin’s construction. Also known as The Descendant of Genghis Khan. Cast includes Valeri Inkizhinov. This fully restored and digitally remastered version contains an original score by Timothy Brock performed by the Olympia Chamber Orchestra.

results.title: The General [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Buster Keaton, Clyde Bruckman, Joseph Schenck, United Artists Corporation and Buster Keaton Productions
results.brief_description: Keaton’s best, and arguably the greatest screen comedy ever made. Against a meticulously evoked Civil War background, Buster risks life, limb and love as he pursues his beloved railway engine, hijacked by Northern spies up to no good for the Southern cause. The result is everything one could wish for; witty, dramatic, visually stunning, full of subtle, delightful human insights, and constantly hilarious. Cast includes Buster Keaton and Marion Mack.

results.title: The Beachcomber = Vessel of wrath
results.creator_credit: Erich Pommer and Mayflower Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Ginger Ted is a dissolute beachcomber, a drunken remittance man (the ‘black sheep’ of an upper class English family being paid to stay away) residing on an island in the Archipelagos. Ted revels in the squalor there, enjoying an endless supply of liquor and the charms of a local girl. A Dutch missionary’s pious sister, Martha Jones, takes an exceptional dislike to Ted, proclaiming him a corrupting influence. Her attitude toward him shifts however when the two are briefly stranded on an island. Shortly afterwards Martha heads off to a remote community where she is determined to counteract an outbreak of cholera. But her efforts are misguided; whilst distributing an antidote she is riled by the natives’ rituals and swiftly earns their wrath. Ted manages to protect her and the pair, inevitably, are romantically united. Laughton succeeds well here with his portrayal of Ted, a slovenly drunkard whose attitude toward the local populace is far more tolerant than the parochial and condescending Martha. Cast also includes Elsa Lanchester and Robert Newton. Based on the tale “Vessel of wrath” by W. Somerset Maugham.

results.title: The Magnificent rebel
results.creator_credit: Georg Tressler and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: A journey into Ludwig van Beethoven’s incredible life of music starring Carl Boehm, an Austrian actor-classical pianist, as Beethoven. The story begins in 1792 in Vienna where Beethoven, aged 22, is studying music and composition under one of the music masters of the time, Joseph Haydn. It is Beethoven’s early period when his enthusiasm is ahead of his ability, particularly in the high classical style, but it is also a time for him to establish himself as a pianist and a composer and earn an income. Beethoven struggled for many years to be accepted by the music discerning public and it was not until he composed his dramatic and tumultuous Symphony No. 5 that he eventually was widely acclaimed by his audience and became recognised on an international level. Now begins his middle period (around 1809 onwards), a time of prolific creativity and writing of symphonies, piano concertos and chamber music. However Beethoven also discovers that he has a hearing disorder that will eventually lead to profound deafness. So follows a period of torment, self-isolation and despair until an encounter and subsequent friendship with a young blind boy awakens Beethoven’s creative spirit to lead him into the late period of his musical career, a calmer and more mature period. The film climaxes with the “piece de resistance”, Beethoven’s Symphony No. 9. Cast also includes Giulia Rubini and Ivan Desny.

results.title: Lady of burlesque
results.creator_credit: William Wellman, Hunt Stromberg and Hunt Stromberg Productions
results.brief_description: Set in the late 1930s, this backstage mystery-comedy stars Barbara Stanwyck as Dixie Daisy, a burlesque artist who also arbitrates frequent disagreements between the chorus girls. When two girls are strangled with a G-string, the police point the finger at various crew members including Daisy and Biff (Michael O’Shea), a comic with designs on Daisy. Stanwyck plays Daisy as a tough-as-nails no-nonsense broad with enough chutzpah to carry the show, whose dialogue at times has a Howard Hawks-esque quality. This is a well-mounted independent production by a veteran ex-Metro producer with an authentic backstage atmosphere and directed at a fast pace by Wellman. Stanwyck sings “Take it off the E-string, Play it on the G-string” while dancing a ‘strip’ number. Also features: J. Edward Bromberg, Charles Dingle, and Frank Conroy. The film attracted an Oscar nomination for music score and Edith Head designed the costumes worn by Barbara Stanwyck. Based on a novel by the famed striptease artist Gypsy Rose Lee.

results.title: Happy go lovely
results.creator_credit: Bruce Humberstone, Marcel Hellman and Associated British Picture Corporation
results.brief_description: This Anglo-American musical/comedy “Happy go lovely” is set in Edinburgh, Scotland, during the Edinburgh festival. A desperate theatre director is staving off creditors and his production hangs in the balance when his leading star quits. None of his crew have been paid properly and are demanding remuneration. Janet Jones (Vera Ellen) is a chorus girl mistaken for the fiancee of local multi-millionaire B.G. Bruno. As a result she is promoted to leading lady and showered in gifts from local dress stores. Rumours drift back to Bruno about Miss Jones and when he calls on her she mistakes him for a reporter, Charlie. As Charlie/Bruno woos Janet complications ensue in a classic case of mistaken identity. The film features numerous song and dance sequences, many of which are in the style of ballet.

results.title: Stevie
results.brief_description: Born in Yorkshire, England in 1902, Florence Margaret “Stevie” Smith began writing poetry in her twenties. Her father left when she was very young and her mother died when she was a teenager, leaving Stevie and her sister under the loving care of their spinster aunt. Stevie was officially recognised with the Chomondeley Award for Poetry in 1966 and the Queen’s Gold Medal for Poetry in 1969. She died of a brain tumor in 1971. The film “Stevie” is literally based on Hugh Whitemore’s play and the works of Stevie Smith to present an historical and biographical look at Stevie’s life. It explores the loving relationship between Stevie (Glenda Jackson) and her Aunt (Mona Washbourne), the romantic liaisons in Stevie’s life, and the eventual fame that her poetic writings bring, using flashbacks and direct dialogue with the audience by Stevie and “The Man” (Trevor Howard). This is very much a stage play on film with not a lot of cinematic expression or extravagant landscapes, confined most of the time to the living room scenes of the house where Stevie and her Aunt dwell. However, it is the literary merit and the art of language which perhaps give this film its appeal, not to mention the excellent performances by some of Britain’s most highly acclaimed actors. Cast also includes Alex McCowan. Winner of many awards including Montreal Film Festival, New York Film Critics Circle Awards, and nominated for BAFTA and Golden Globe Awards.

results.title: Shall we dance?
results.creator_credit: Masayuki Suo, Yuji Ogata, Shoji Masui, Tetsuya Ikeda, Nihon Terebi, Nihon Eiga Shin-sha, Hakuhodo, Daiei Motion Picture Company and Altamira Pictures
results.brief_description: Suo’s second feature after his offbeat comic debut “Sumo Do, Sumo Don’t”, this wistful comedy about a Japanese salaryman who discovers the joys of ballroom dancing was hugely successful in its country of origin. Each evening, as he commutes home to his wife and daughter, Shohei Sugiyama, a typically strait-laced Japanese businessmen, catches a glimpse of a beautiful woman gazing out the window of a dance school. Unable to contain his curiosity, he enrols for classes in order to make contact with her. A snooty ex-professional dancer, she keeps her distance from Sugiyama, but through his newfound love of dancing he befriends a group of people who share his secret passion, including an office colleague who becomes a flamboyant mambo king on the dance floor. Touching and uplifting, the film also offers a subtle critique of restrictive cultural norms in a country where ballroom dancing is regarded as a slightly embarrassing, suspicious past-time because of the close physical proximity of the dancers. Cast includes Koji Yakusho, Taoiyo Kusakari, Naoto Takenaka and Eriko Watanabe. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Yol
results.creator_credit: Yilmaz Guney, Serif Goren, Edi Hubschmid, DRS, Schweizer Fernselen, Maran Film, Guney Film, Films A2 and Cactus Films
results.brief_description: Five political prisoners are given one week’s reprieve to go and visit their families. One man returns to find that his adulterous wife is being kept prisoner by his father-in-law who expects him to kill her. Another returns to his village but cannot marry the woman he loves because custom decrees he must marry his widowed sister-in-law; another finds his family has shunned him for confessing to the authorities. As the men spread out across Turkey’s vast terrain, “Yol” explores the strictures of tradition on family and on marriage. The men, all of whom must return to their prison cells, are prisoners of an authoritarian state. Their women and their children are prisoners of an equally authoritarian patriarchy. Guney was himself a political prisoner, incarcerated for his intellectual activism against state militarism, when he wrote the script to “Yol”, which was smuggled out to Serif Goren, who directed the film for Guney. Guney escaped to Switzerland where he completed the film. Though the social, political and gender relationships explored in the film are harsh and unrelenting, what is transcendant about “Yol” is the deeply rigorous humanism that Guney and Goren extend to all their characters. That Guney and Goren were able to complete the film is a testament itself to their intelligence and dedication to a cinema of enlightenment. This film is one of cinema’s greatest laments against the violence of patriarchy and one of the great emancipist works about the possibilities of change and transformation. (Awards: Winner of the Palme d’Or at Cannes. Winner of the International Critic’s Prize) In Turkish with English subtitles.

results.description: Five political prisoners are given one week’s reprieve to go and visit their families. One man returns to find that his adulterous wife is being kept prisoner by his father-in-law who expects him to kill her. Another returns to his village but cannot marry the woman he loves because custom decrees he must marry his widowed sister-in-law; another finds his family has shunned him for confessing to the authorities. As the men spread out across Turkey’s vast terrain, “Yol” explores the strictures of tradition on family and on marriage. The men, all of whom must return to their prison cells, are prisoners of an authoritarian state. Their women and their children are prisoners of an equally authoritarian patriarchy.
